messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, yeah, I agree on those Owari, I saw one at Yashima 2 years ago and opted for a Joushin Futokoromono and I have been kicking myself ever since lol. They
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim, yeah, I agree on those Owari, I saw one at Yashima 2 years ago
and opted for a Joushin Futokoromono and I have been kicking myself ever
since lol. They were about the same price.

I am brining it over to Sydney so you can have a look if you come.

Rich



Richard Turner
小道具の世界 – Kodôgu no Sekai
http://kodogunosekai.com/

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: It looks much less extreme in that photo, Rich and I d agree not a problem.  The Owari guards I really like tend to have fine-grained, lusterous metal on the
messages.messageBody:
It looks much less extreme in that photo, Rich and I'd agree not a
problem. The Owari guards I really like tend to have fine-grained,
lusterous metal on the rim with subtle lenticular and running tekotsu.
They're rather rare though.

Jim

Visit Baja Sur?

http://www.flickr.com/photos/jggilbert/sets/72157623839030000/

flaw personally, and as I noted, my photo does seem to accentuate the

effect. This is a pic from the dealer I bought it from, which is

probably closer to the real look in hand I think.



http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6140/5959991154_bed285a420_z.jpg



Cheers



Rich



Richard Turner

messages.msgSnippet: ko-akasaka. See mimi in 3rd, 4th, 5th photo: http://www.tsuruginoya.com/mn1_3/f00143.html ... From: Jim Gilbert  Subject: Re:
messages.messageBody:
ko-akasaka.
See mimi in 3rd, 4th, 5th photo:
http://www.tsuruginoya.com/mn1_3/f00143.html


--- On Wed, 7/20/11, Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:

From: Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...>
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, July 20, 2011, 8:33 PM
















 











The story about Akasaka is not that they are three-fold, but three-layered.

They are supposed to have been forged from two outer layers of harder

steel sandwiching a softer center. Reality is somewhat different with

early Akasaka guards showing an inconsistent variety of forging schemes

and layering.



I've never run across any particular story or

reality with the forging of Owari guards. The good ones I've handled are

quite tightly welded. Visible layers in a guard are often the result

of rust or fire. Voids in the outer rim like that are rather suspect - I

doubt that guards were let out of the shop like that. But, it looks

like it's in good condition otherwise, so who knows.



Regarding the reference to an "Owari" guard in a KTK catalog... I would approach

those books with caution as reference material.



Jim



Visit Midway Atoll?



http://www.flickr.com/photos/jggilbert/sets/72157626224419365/



-----Original Message-----



From: Ron Hartmann



Sent: Jul 14, 2011 1:19 PM



To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com



Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba



Beautiful tsuba! I recall reading about the 3-fold of Akasaka and just maybe...something about the more simple 2-fold forging. That "maybe" means if so, I've no recollection of where I might have seen this. Perhaps in one of the in-depth discussions on Owari?



Ron



STL



----- Original Message -----



From: Richard Turner



To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com



Sent: Wednesday, July 13, 2011 6:28 PM



Subject: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba



(In case the original does not come though)



Hi all, I recently purchased this Momoyama Owari sukashi I have had my



eye on for a while. Fairly classic design and at 81mm x 80mm x 5.5mm it



is a nice size. One of the traits here that I find most interesting is



the mimi, and the obvious fold line that appears in it (it covers about



30% of the mimi). it is almost like the tsuba was made from a two plate



construction, though I am not suggesting that at all. I assume the



original plate was forged, then folded and forged again before shaping.



I cannot nay that I have seen this so clearly before in an Owari guard



before ( I will also note that I got it to jump out a bit with some



clever lighting etc) and wondered if it was a normal trait in Owari works.



I really love the iron on this guard, its been well forged and is in



really good condition.



http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5934784209_807a0a2719_b.jpg



http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6132/5934784543_7aa87f9b4a_b.jpg



http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5935345246_1aa21c6a64_b.jpg



Cheers



Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: The story about Akasaka is not that they are three-fold, but three-layered. They are supposed to have been forged from two outer layers of harder steel
messages.messageBody:
The story about Akasaka is not that they are three-fold, but three-layered.
They are supposed to have been forged from two outer layers of harder
steel sandwiching a softer center. Reality is somewhat different with
early Akasaka guards showing an inconsistent variety of forging schemes
and layering.

I've never run across any particular story or
reality with the forging of Owari guards. The good ones I've handled are
quite tightly welded. Visible layers in a guard are often the result
of rust or fire. Voids in the outer rim like that are rather suspect - I
doubt that guards were let out of the shop like that. But, it looks
like it's in good condition otherwise, so who knows.

Regarding the reference to an "Owari" guard in a KTK catalog... I would approach
those books with caution as reference material.

Jim

Visit Midway Atoll?

http://www.flickr.com/photos/jggilbert/sets/72157626224419365/


-----Original Message-----

From: Ron Hartmann

Sent: Jul 14, 2011 1:19 PM

To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba




























Beautiful tsuba! I recall reading about the 3-fold of Akasaka and just maybe...something about the more simple 2-fold forging. That "maybe" means if so, I've no recollection of where I might have seen this. Perhaps in one of the in-depth discussions on Owari?



Ron

STL



----- Original Message -----

From: Richard Turner

To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

Sent: Wednesday, July 13, 2011 6:28 PM

Subject: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba



(In case the original does not come though)



Hi all, I recently purchased this Momoyama Owari sukashi I have had my

eye on for a while. Fairly classic design and at 81mm x 80mm x 5.5mm it

is a nice size. One of the traits here that I find most interesting is

the mimi, and the obvious fold line that appears in it (it covers about

30% of the mimi). it is almost like the tsuba was made from a two plate

construction, though I am not suggesting that at all. I assume the

original plate was forged, then folded and forged again before shaping.



I cannot nay that I have seen this so clearly before in an Owari guard

before ( I will also note that I got it to jump out a bit with some

clever lighting etc) and wondered if it was a normal trait in Owari works.



I really love the iron on this guard, its been well forged and is in

really good condition.



http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5934784209_807a0a2719_b.jpg



http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6132/5934784543_7aa87f9b4a_b.jpg



http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5935345246_1aa21c6a64_b.jpg



Cheers



Rich

messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard, thanks for that. I do not have that catalogue, I don't
suppose you have an image of that by any chance lol ? I assume you are
referring to hand wear with the 10-12 o'clock comment ? I have another
Owari with that feature that revealed tekkotsu underneath.

http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6125/5938563418_10ca2b41ae_b.jpg

http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6010/5938563398_cae1cb1acf_b.jpg

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Richard - I took a look at the 2010 KTK publication. That was an Owari tsuba and it mentions 3-fold forging.  Maybe upon closer inspection, Rich s tsuba might
messages.messageBody:
Richard -

I took a look at the 2010 KTK publication. That was an Owari tsuba and it mentions 3-fold forging. Maybe upon closer inspection, Rich's tsuba might also reveal the 3-fold forging instead of simply a folded over forging.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard George
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, July 14, 2011 12:42 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba



Rich,

I don't know about typical, but I shot an owari piece for the KTK's 2010
catalog where you could clearly see the layers inside of the sukashi
(particularly around
the 10-12 o'clock position where the hand would rest a lot...). There's
an oblique image in the catalog showing that.

Best,

rkg
(Richard George)

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Beautiful tsuba! I recall reading about the 3-fold of Akasaka and just maybe...something about the more simple 2-fold forging. That maybe means if so, I ve
messages.messageBody:
Beautiful tsuba! I recall reading about the 3-fold of Akasaka and just maybe...something about the more simple 2-fold forging. That "maybe" means if so, I've no recollection of where I might have seen this. Perhaps in one of the in-depth discussions on Owari?

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, July 13, 2011 6:28 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba



(In case the original does not come though)

Hi all, I recently purchased this Momoyama Owari sukashi I have had my
eye on for a while. Fairly classic design and at 81mm x 80mm x 5.5mm it
is a nice size. One of the traits here that I find most interesting is
the mimi, and the obvious fold line that appears in it (it covers about
30% of the mimi). it is almost like the tsuba was made from a two plate
construction, though I am not suggesting that at all. I assume the
original plate was forged, then folded and forged again before shaping.

I cannot nay that I have seen this so clearly before in an Owari guard
before ( I will also note that I got it to jump out a bit with some
clever lighting etc) and wondered if it was a normal trait in Owari works.

I really love the iron on this guard, its been well forged and is in
really good condition.

http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5934784209_807a0a2719_b.jpg

http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6132/5934784543_7aa87f9b4a_b.jpg

http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5935345246_1aa21c6a64_b.jpg

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Owari sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: The heart is the spade upside down.   The mitsukawabishi is the diamond, and the last symbol is the club.   Excuse me, I have to go back  to the bar. ...
messages.messageBody:
The heart is the spade upside down. The mitsukawabishi is the diamond, and the last symbol is the club. Excuse me, I have to go back to the bar.
On Jul 14, 2011, at 5:28 AM, Richard Turner wrote:

> mmm, I must not be drinking the right stuff, I only see 3 designs there
>
> Rich
>
> On 14/07/2011 11:45 AM, Robert Schleimer wrote:
> >
> > Looks like clubs, diamonds, hearts and spades!
> > On Jul 13, 2011, at 6:28 PM, Richard Turner wrote:

> > > 30% of the mimi). it is almost like the tsuba was made from a two plate
> > > construction, though I am not suggesting that at all. I assume the
> > > original plate was forged, then folded and forged again before shaping.
> > >
> > > I cannot nay that I have seen this so clearly before in an Owari guard

> > > clever lighting etc) and wondered if it was a normal trait in Owari
> > works.

> > > I really love the iron on this guard, its been well forged and is in
> > > really good condition.

Looks like clubs, diamonds, hearts and spades!
On Jul 13, 2011, at 6:28 PM, Richard Turner wrote:

> (In case the original does not come though)
>
> Hi all, I recently purchased this Momoyama Owari sukashi I have had my
> eye on for a while. Fairly classic design and at 81mm x 80mm x 5.5mm it
> is a nice size. One of the traits here that I find most interesting is
> the mimi, and the obvious fold line that appears in it (it covers about
> 30% of the mimi). it is almost like the tsuba was made from a two plate
> construction, though I am not suggesting that at all. I assume the
> original plate was forged, then folded and forged again before shaping.
>
> I cannot nay that I have seen this so clearly before in an Owari guard
> before ( I will also note that I got it to jump out a bit with some
> clever lighting etc) and wondered if it was a normal trait in Owari works.
>
> I really love the iron on this guard, its been well forged and is in
> really good condition.
>
> http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5934784209_807a0a2719_b.jpg
>
> http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6132/5934784543_7aa87f9b4a_b.jpg
>
> http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5935345246_1aa21c6a64_b.jpg
>
> Cheers
>
> Rich
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>

messages.subject: Owari sukashi tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: (In case the original does not come though) Hi all, I recently purchased this Momoyama Owari sukashi I have had my eye on for a while. Fairly classic design
messages.messageBody:
(In case the original does not come though)

Hi all, I recently purchased this Momoyama Owari sukashi I have had my
eye on for a while. Fairly classic design and at 81mm x 80mm x 5.5mm it
is a nice size. One of the traits here that I find most interesting is
the mimi, and the obvious fold line that appears in it (it covers about
30% of the mimi). it is almost like the tsuba was made from a two plate
construction, though I am not suggesting that at all. I assume the
original plate was forged, then folded and forged again before shaping.

I cannot nay that I have seen this so clearly before in an Owari guard
before ( I will also note that I got it to jump out a bit with some
clever lighting etc) and wondered if it was a normal trait in Owari works.

I really love the iron on this guard, its been well forged and is in
really good condition.

http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5934784209_807a0a2719_b.jpg

http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6132/5934784543_7aa87f9b4a_b.jpg

http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6144/5935345246_1aa21c6a64_b.jpg

Cheers

Rich

messages.msgSnippet: Richard, Were these all from various back issues of the NCJSC Newsletter? I recall finding one or two in really old JSS/US publications, and then there are his
messages.messageBody:
Richard,

Were these all from various back issues of the NCJSC Newsletter?

I recall finding one or two in really old JSS/US publications, and then
there are his writings as part of publications like "100 Selected Tsuba from
European Public Collections."

Craig

Craig Harris
Bridge of Dreams, LLC
Books from and about Asia
www.bridgeofdreams.com
Member, IOBA, Independent Online Booksellers Association
Member, MWABA, Midwest Antiquarian Booksellers Association

messages.subject: Robert Haynes Articles
messages.msgSnippet: I just found three articles by Robert Haynes that I believe Richard Turner put on his web-site. My question is - were there more than three articles and if
messages.messageBody: I just found three articles by Robert Haynes that I believe Richard Turner put on his web-site. My question is - were there more than three articles and if there were, where can I find them to read?
